citations.narrative:
Primary enclosures failed to protect dogs from injury. Upon reviewing Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee
(IACUC) meeting minutes, four adult dogs, from July 2024-June 2025, were injured as a result from getting a paw trapped
in the primary enclosures. Two of the dogs had minor injuries characterized by swelling, a puncture wound, and
temporary limping. One dog, male Beagle #4989857, had a bar from the cage door through the webbing in between two
toes on the left front paw. The welding on the bottom of the bar had become loose and the dog’s paw slipped underneath
it. Animal care staff found the dog on March 11, 2025, after morning rounds and during second morning checks, with its
paw stuck underneath the bar. Another dog, female Beagle #1363320, was found in the morning of July 22, 2024, with
her second digit (toe) of the right front paw caught in the food bowl holder. The dog was released from the holder and
upon examination and subsequent x-ray, the middle bone (middle phalanx) of the second toe was fractured. The dog had
surgery and recovered uneventfully. In all cases mentioned above, veterinary records were reviewed and all dogs
received appropriate veterinary care.
Injuries and entrapment can cause pain and stress to the affected animals. Primary enclosures must be constructed in a
way to protect the animals housed within from injury. The facility has identified these enclosures as needing improvement
and has taken steps to modify and/or replace them prior to today’s inspection.
Correct by: June 23, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.6(a)(2)(ii)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
Primary enclosures failed to protect dogs from injury. Upon reviewing Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee 
(IACUC) meeting minutes, four adult dogs, from July 2024-June 2025, were injured as a result from getting a paw trapped 
in the primary enclosures. Two of the dogs had minor injuries characterized by swelling, a puncture wound, and 
temporary limping. One dog, male Beagle #4989857, had a bar from the cage door through the webbing in between two 
toes on the left front paw. The welding on the bottom of the bar had become loose and the dog’s paw slipped underneath 
it. Animal care staff found the dog on March 11, 2025, after morning rounds and during second morning checks, with its 
paw stuck underneath the bar. Another dog, female Beagle #1363320, was found in the morning of July 22, 2024, with 
her second digit (toe) of the right front paw caught in the food bowl holder. The dog was released from the holder and 
upon examination and subsequent x-ray, the middle bone (middle phalanx) of the second toe was fractured. The dog had 
surgery and recovered uneventfully. In all cases mentioned above, veterinary records were reviewed and all dogs 
received appropriate veterinary care. 
 
Injuries and entrapment can cause pain and stress to the affected animals. Primary enclosures must be constructed in a 
way to protect the animals housed within from injury. The facility has identified these enclosures as needing improvement 
and has taken steps to modify and/or replace them prior to today’s inspection. 
 
Correct by: June 23, 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives. 
 
 n
